title: Delete selected
content: This workshop will show you how to implement deletion of nodes and edges.

title: Vizdom layout
content: This is an example of using the vizdom library for computing layout.

title: D3 Force
content: This is a simple example of using the d3-force layout package.

title: Default nodes
content: To get started, you just need to provide nodes array to vflow component.

title: Default edges
content: You can link nodes with edges. All you need to do is to create another Edge[] array and pass it to the vflow component. Each edge contains the id of the source and target nodes, and each edge must have its own id.

title: Snap to Grid
content: You can snap nodes to the grid by passing the snapGrid input to the VflowComponent

title: Unit testing component nodes
content: To simplify writing isolated tests for component nodes, you can use the provideCustomNodeMocks function. This helps prevent dependency injection (DI) errors that occur when a node is used outside the scope of the VflowComponent.

title: Stress Test
content: The library can render 1000+ nodes instantly while maintaining smooth user interactions.

title: Roadmap
content: This is a roadmap for ngx-vflow:

title: Markers
content: You can create markers for both edges and connections.

title: Markers
content: Edges: Specify start and end markers for corresponding parts of the edge. Currently, markers are limited to two types: arrow and arrow-closed.Connections: You can specify an end marker using the marker property in ConnectionSettings.

title: NodeAccessorService
content: Service to fix cyclic dependency between node and resizable component

title: Multiple connection points
content: Custom components provide the ability to control handles and their positions.

title: Multiple connection points
content: All you need to do is take HandleComponent from library and place it somewhere in your custom node. This component automatically computes its position based on parent element's position.

title: Drag and drop nodes
content: This workshop will show you how to implement dynamic node creation with basic drag and drop functionality. It also demonstrates how to attach nodes to groups or detach them from groups.

title: Drag and drop nodes
content: This implementation uses the following APIs from VflowComponent:

title: Drag and drop nodes
content: documentPointToFlowPoint() to get a stack of SpacePointsgetIntersectingNodes() to get intersections between nodes during drag operationstoNodeSpace() to get a node's position in the coordinate system of another node

title: Floating Edges
content: The library supports floating edges. A floating edge is an edge that connects the closest handles of the source and target nodes. You can enable floating edges using the floating flag on Edge.

title: Floating Edges
content: Since the library always looks for the closest handles between nodes, there can only be one edge between any two nodes. Keep this in mind when building your flows.

title: Floating Edges
content: This limitation may be addressed in future releases.

title: ConnectEndEvent
content: The side where the connection started from

title: ConnectEndEvent
content: The side where the connection ended to

title: ReconnectEndEvent
content: The side where the edge remain attached during reconnection

title: ReconnectEndEvent
content: The side where the edge was reconnected to

title: FlowSettingsService
content: Set based on view property. May change if view is 'auto'

title: FlowSettingsService
content: Set based on view property. May change if view is 'auto'

title: RootPointerDirective
content: We should know when user started a touch in order to not show old touch position when connection creation is started

title: SpacePointContextDirective
content: Signal with current mouse position in svg space

title: Node toolbar
content: You can add a NodeToolbarComponent to your node. The content of this component is automatically positioned near one side of the node, based on the value of the position input.

title: Node toolbar
content: It's also possible to add multiple toolbars to the same node by simply including multiple NodeToolbarComponent instances with different position inputs.

title: Alignment Helper
content: The library supports alignment lines that help align nodes relative to each other. To enable this feature, pass the [alignmentHelper] input to the VflowComponent. Its value can be either:

title: Alignment Helper
content: true – to enable the helper with default settingsAn AlignmentHelperSettings object – to configure the helper with custom settings

title: Component mocks
content: Starting from version 1.9, you must import mock components from ngx-vflow/testing instead of ngx-vflow. The previous approach caused mock components to be bundled with production components, so the testing code has been moved to a separate entry point.

title: Component mocks
content: The library provides mocks for every public component to simplify testing in a Node environment (e.g., Jest). The naming convention for importing real and mock components follows this pattern: Component → MockComponent. For example, VflowComponent has a corresponding mock, VflowMockComponent.

title: Component mocks
content: In the testing environment, you should replace real components with their mock counterparts. For example, to mock the entire library, you should:

title: Curves
content: It's possible to set Curve for both the edges and connection.

title: Curves
content: If the existing curves do not meet your needs, you can provide your own function that implements the CurveFactory signature.

title: Custom handles
content: You can pass a [template] to HandleComponent with custom handle.

title: Custom handles
content: I't important to note that template must be made with SVG.

title: Custom handles
content: Custom handles are not positioned automatically, but the library provides a useful template context property to position your handle.Custom handles know if validation of ConnectionSettings.validator() has failed or succeeded, so you can use state() signal in let-ctx to add some behavior based on validation result.

title: Custom handles
content: Refer to this interface for let-ctx when crafting your handle template:

title: Draggables
content: You can disable draggable behavior on certain Node by passing false.

title: Draggables
content: You can restrict dragging to a specific part of node, by adding dragHandle directive to this element. It's important to note that if a node contains at least one dragHandle, it can only be dragged from those specific areas where dragHandle was added. Otherwise, the entire node can be dragged, provided the draggable property is set to true.

title: CurveLayout
content: Optional points for label placement along the curve

title: CurveLayout
content: SVG path string defining the curve (d attribute - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Reference/Attribute/d)

title: CustomNodeComponent
content: Reference to node bound to this component

title: CustomNodeComponent
content: Signal with selected state of node

title: HandleModel
content: Pre-computed size for default handle, changed dynamically for custom handles

title: ComponentNodeEvent
content: Generic accepts array of custom components and merge their event emitters for type-safe event handling

title: FitViewOptions
content: Duration of animated transition to new viewport

title: FitViewOptions
content: Nodes that should be visible after fitView. The whole flow will be visible if not passed or passed an empty array

title: View size
content: vflow automatically fits it container if you pass view="auto" input

title: View size
content: vflow can take fixed space if you pass [view]="[600, 600]" input, where first item of array is width (in pixels), and the second is height (in pixels).

title: Subflows
content: A subflow is a node that can contain child nodes. Key things about subflows:

title: Subflows
content: To create a subflow, you need to use a default-group or template-group type on Node.To associate a node with a subflow, set the parentId to the ID of the subflow.Nodes within a subflow have coordinates relative to that subflow.A subflow is itself a node, so it can act as a source or a target (this functionality is available only for template-group subflows).Use the groupNode directive on an ng-template to define your custom subflow. While a custom subflow can theoretically be any SVG structure, it's recommended to use the

title: HandleComponent
content: Should be used if node has more than one source/target

title: HandleComponent
content: At what side of node this component should be placed

title: ConnectionControllerDirective
content: This event fires when user tries to create new Edge.

title: ConnectionControllerDirective
content: Connection is an entity that contains data about source and target nodes.

title: ConnectionControllerDirective
content: Also it's important to note, that this event only fires when connection is valid by validator function in ConnectionSettings, by default without passing the validator every connection concidered valid.

title: ViewportService
content: Public signal with viewport state. User can directly read from this signal. It's updated by:

title: ViewportService
content: Internal signal that accepts value from user by lib api When this signal changes, lib sets new view state and update readableViewport signal

title: Architecture
content: This topic needs some clarification due to the design decisions behind the library.

title: Architecture
content: The library renders the flow by combining two technologies:

title: Architecture
content: SVG, which is responsible for rendering curves, managing zoom, pan, and other tasks that SVG handles well.HTML (with CSS), which is used to create the content for the nodes, allowing front-end engineers to design dynamic and visually appealing UIs more easily than with SVG.

title: Architecture
content: The link between these two technologies is the

title: Architecture
content: element, which enables HTML to be rendered inside SVG. The diagram below illustrates how this element interacts with its content.

title: Minimap
content: The library includes a minimap that offers an overview of the entire flow. To enable it, simply add a

title: Minimap
content: component as a direct child of

title: Minimap
content: . For customization options, see the available inputs in MiniMapComponent.

title: Minimap
content: Develop an API to customize mini-node appearance (e.g., color, stroke)Enable panning and zooming within the minimapRender mini-nodes to visually match main nodes, using a simplified DOM structure to optimize performance

title: Overview
content: ngx-vflow is an Angular library for creating node-based applications. It aims to assist you in building anything from a static diagram to a visual editor. You can utilize the default design or apply your own by customizing everything using familiar technologies.

title: Overview
content: Easy to use: Just describe your flow with a simple API; all of the heavy lifting, such as dragging, zooming, and curve math, is handled by the library for you.

title: Overview
content: Customizable: There is a default design for basic usage, and you can also customize nodes with good old HTML and CSS. Other entities such as edges, connection lines, and handles are also customizable, but it will require a little SVG knowledge.

title: Overview
content: Great performance: Angular signals are the heart and soul of ngx-vflow, which are performant by default, so you shouldn't worry about performance even with large flows.

title: MiniMapComponent
content: The color outside the viewport (invisible area)

title: MiniMapComponent
content: The corner of the flow where to render a mini-map

title: MiniMapComponent
content: Make a minimap bigger on hover

title: ImageBackground
content: If true, image will be fixed on the background (not moving with the flow, zoom also doesn't affect it)

title: ImageBackground
content: If true, image will be repeated

title: ImageBackground
content: Scale relative to natural image size.

title: ImageBackground
content: For example, if image is 100x100 and scale is 0.5, it will be rendered as 50x50

title: ImageBackground
content: Path to image. Passes as a href to this element:

title: Optimization
content: If true, the layer with groups will be placed behind the edges layer. This approach fixes the issue when you can't select an edge inside group.

title: Optimization
content: The trigger for lazy loading of entities.

title: Optimization
content: If true, enables viewport virtualization to improve performance by only rendering nodes and edges that are currently visible in the viewport. This optimization filters out entities that are outside the visible area, reducing the number of DOM elements and improving rendering performance for large flows.

title: Optimization
content: It uses canvas as a virtualization layer during viewport change. When the viewport change ends, the library hydrates the canvas with the actual nodes and edges.

title: Optimization
content: The zoom threshold below which the only virtualization layer is drawn. This should help to avoid performance issues when zooming out too much.

title: CurveFactorySharedParams
content: Array of all edges in the flow

title: CurveFactorySharedParams
content: Array of all nodes in the flow

title: CurveFactorySharedParams
content: Starting point coordinates of the curve

title: CurveFactorySharedParams
content: Position of the source handle relative to the source node

title: CurveFactorySharedParams
content: Ending point coordinates of the curve

title: CurveFactorySharedParams
content: Position of the target handle relative to the target node

title: Lazy Loading
content: Open the network tab in DevTools to see components being loaded dynamically.

title: Lazy Loading
content: The library supports splitting a large flow into multiple chunks, where each chunk is loaded according to the provided lazyLoadTrigger in the Optimization object.

title: Lazy Loading
content: To load nodes when the viewport changes, set lazyLoadTrigger to the value viewport.

title: Lazy Loading
content: To adapt your existing component nodes, replace component constructor calls in the type field with dynamic import factories:

title: Lazy Loading
content: For template nodes, the library provides a custom trigger for the @defer syntax through the context.

title: Virtualization
content: This is an experimental API. The library still does not support edge previews - only node previews are available.

title: Virtualization
content: The library supports virtualization, which helps improve performance when rendering large numbers of nodes. When virtualization is enabled, an additional canvas layer is activated alongside the existing SVG layer.

title: Virtualization
content: During viewport changes (zoom/pan), the canvas layer quickly renders lightweight preview nodes to ensure smooth interaction. Once the interaction ends, these preview nodes are hydrated into full-featured, heavy SVG nodes.

title: Virtualization
content: To enable virtualization, set the virtualization flag in the Optimization interface. Additionally, you can use the virtualizationZoomThreshold property to specify the minimum zoom level at which previews should be rendered. This helps avoid performance issues by rendering a lot of real SVG nodes.

title: Virtualization
content: It's important to note that a preview node is a simplified version of a real node. It is rendered on the canvas layer, is not interactive, and may not visually match the real node exactly (at least for now) — hence the name preview.

title: Virtualization
content: However, the library aims to provide a good API for customizing these previews. The NodePreview interface allows you to style preview nodes using a subset of CSSStyleDeclaration, letting you write familiar, declarative CSS instead of low-level canvas code. The library automatically compiles these styles into appropriate canvas calls.

title: Virtualization
content: To customize the preview for a specific node, use the preview property available on Node.

title: NodeModel
content: If resizer is used, the node size fully depends on the resizer Otherwise it calculates the size based on the content

title: ConnectionCurveFactoryParams
content: Array of all edges in the flow

title: ConnectionCurveFactoryParams
content: Array of all nodes in the flow

title: ConnectionCurveFactoryParams
content: Indicates this is a temporary connection being drawn

title: ConnectionCurveFactoryParams
content: Starting point coordinates of the curve

title: ConnectionCurveFactoryParams
content: Position of the source handle relative to the source node

title: ConnectionCurveFactoryParams
content: Ending point coordinates of the curve

title: ConnectionCurveFactoryParams
content: Position of the target handle relative to the target node

title: EdgeCurveFactoryParams
content: Array of all edges in the flow

title: EdgeCurveFactoryParams
content: Array of all nodes in the flow

title: EdgeCurveFactoryParams
content: The edge instance this curve belongs to

title: EdgeCurveFactoryParams
content: Indicates this is a permanent edge

title: EdgeCurveFactoryParams
content: Starting point coordinates of the curve

content: Position of the source handle relative to the source node

title: EdgeCurveFactoryParams
content: Ending point coordinates of the curve

title: EdgeCurveFactoryParams
content: Position of the target handle relative to the target node

title: Selecting
content: Nodes and edges can be selected!

title: Selecting
content: Default nodes and edges are selectable by default; just click and see that one is selected.

title: Selecting
content: Custom nodes and edges are not selectable by default, you need to mark the element that triggers selection with the

title: Selecting
content: Both custom nodes and edges have the selected() signal in their template context for applying styles based on this state.

title: Selecting
content: if you want disable selecting for whole flow.

title: Custom background
content: You're able to select background for your flow.

title: Custom background
content: To select a color, simply pass a color string it to the [background] input.

title: Custom background
content: To make dots pattern, pass an object to the [background] input according to DotsBackground interface

title: Custom background
content: To make an image background, pass an object to the [background] input according to ImageBackground interface

title: Custom background
content: To make grid pattern, pass an object to the [background] input according to GridBackground interface

title: SVG Nodes
content: SVG nodes allow you to create custom node shapes using SVG elements. To create an SVG node:

title: SVG Nodes
content: Access node properties via the template context (

content: The template context has the following type:

title: Labels
content: You can attach labels to edges by providing the edgeLabels property to the Edges. There are three slots available for labels on an edge: start, center, and end.

title: Labels
content: There are several ways a label can appear on an edge.

title: Labels
content: This method renders simple static text on the edge. To achieve this, you need to:

title: Labels
content: Pass the default type to EdgeLabel.Set the text.Optionally add the style, which supports any CSS property.

title: Labels
content: This method renders complex HTML on the edge. To achieve this, you need to:

title: Labels
content: Pass the html-template type to EdgeLabel.Provide the

title: Labels
content: inside vflow.Optionally pass any data that will be accessible in the template context.

title: Labels
content: You may access some data for label through let-ctx according to this interface.

title: Showcase
content: Over the past two years, ngx-vflow has gained popularity in the community, and this list showcases the most remarkable and interesting projects that relies on the library.

title: Showcase
content: Agent Development Kit Web is the built-in developer UI that integrated with Google Agent Development Kit for easier agent development and debug.

title: Showcase
content: The ADK Visual Builder is a web-based tool that provides a visual workflow design environment for creating and managing ADK agents. It allows you to design, build, and test your agents in a beginner-friendly graphical interface, and includes an AI-powered assistant to help you build agents.

title: Showcase
content: The open source, cloud native tool for API Mocking and Testing. Microcks is a Cloud Native Computing Foundation sandbox project 🚀

title: Keyboard shortcuts
content: You can use keyboard shortcuts to perform additional actions.

title: Keyboard shortcuts
content: To customize the keyboard shortcuts for specific actions, pass a [keyboardShortcuts] input object to the VflowComponent with the following KeyboardShortcuts interface. Here are some key details:

title: Keyboard shortcuts
content: The passed object will be merged with the default key combinations.To disable a specific action, pass null for that action.If you want to trigger an action with multiple keys, pass an array of keys. Note: this is not a key combination. For example, if you pass ['ShiftLeft', 'ControlLeft'], the action will be triggered by either ShiftLeft or ControlLeft, but not by pressing both together (ShiftLeft+ControlLeft).You can find the list of available key codes here.

title: Keyboard shortcuts
content: In the following example, the default combination for multiSelection is replaced with ['ShiftLeft', 'ShiftRight'].

title: Resizer
content: You might want to resize your node. This functionality works with nearly all types of nodes.

title: Resizer
content: To resize a default group, simply pass the resizable flag to a Node of type default-group.

title: Resizer
content: This provides a way to have more control over the resizer:

title: Resizer
content: Create a template-group node.If you want the resizer to appear consistently, add the resizable directive to the SVG element (likely a

title: Resizer
content: ) representing your group.If you want the resizer to appear conditionally, apply the directive as [resizable]="yourCondition". You can bind the visibility of the resizer to the node’s selection state (see the code below for an example).Important: Use the ctx.width() and ctx.height() signals from the context, not ctx.node.width and ctx.node.height. The latter properties are not reactive, so the node won’t update its size based on the resizer.The resizer respects the min-width and min-height CSS properties of the resizable node.Optionally, you can customize the [resizerColor] and the [gap] between the node and the resizer, with more customization options coming in the future."

title: Resizer
content: The algorithm is almost the same as for template-group nodes:

title: Resizer
content: Create a node of type html-template or CustomNodeComponent (CustomDynamicNodeComponent).If you want the resizer to always appear, add the resizable directive to the top-level element of your custom node (ideally, a wrapper for the entire node content).If you want the resizer to appear conditionally, apply the directive as [resizable]="yourCondition". Binding the visibility of the resizer to the node’s selection state can be useful.The resizer respects the min-width and min-height CSS properties of the element where the directive is applied.It's up to you to adjust the CSS of your custom node to ensure it renders correctly during resizing. The library only modifies the container size.Optionally, you can customize the [resizerColor] and the [gap] between the node and the resizer, with more customization options coming in the future.

title: Resizer
content: You may want to perform some actions on resize. To do this, simply add handler to the (nodesChanges.size) output of the

title: Handling changes
content: You can observe changes in the toasts.

title: Handling changes
content: You can observe various changes in nodes and edges.

title: Handling changes
content: position - new node position after drag and dropsize - new node sizeadd - when node was createdremove - when node was removedselect - when node was selected (also triggers for unselected nodes)

title: Handling changes
content: add - when edge was createdremove - when edge was removedselect - when edge was selected (also triggers for unselected edges)detached - when edge became invisible due to the absence of the source or target node. Use this to delete such edges from the edges list

title: Handling changes
content: There are a several ways to receive these changes:

title: Handling changes
content: This is a way to get every possible change. Changes came as non empty arrays:

content: For your convenience, here is the filtering scheme for changes based on the (nodesChanges) and (edgesChanges) events:

title: Handling changes
content: (nodesChanges.[NodeChangeType]) - a list of node changes of a certain type(nodesChanges.[EdgeChangeType]) - a list of edge changes of a certain type

title: Connections
content: Edges are not created automatically. To create a new edge, follow these steps:

title: Connections
content: , but it doesn't exist in the flow yet—you need to "convert" it into a new

title: Connections
content: list with the new edge that was created from the

title: Connections
content: In the default 'strict' mode of ConnectionSettings, edges are created from connections with strict adherence to the source and target types of the HandleComponent. This means connections can only be established in one direction based on these properties.

title: Connections
content: This is the 'loose' mode of ConnectionSettings, where the flow ignores the handle type and allows any handle to connect with any other handle. In this mode, an id must be provided for the HandleComponent to function correctly.

title: Connections
content: ngx-vflow supports real-time synchronous validation of connections. Validation occurs when a user attempts to create a new edge. By default, every connection is valid, but you can provide a ConnectionSettings with a validator callback where you specify the validation logic.

title: Connections
content: For example, in this case, validation only passes connections from node 1 to node 2. If the validator returns false, the (connect) event won't be triggered because there is no valid connection.

title: Connections
content: Edges can be reconnected. To reconnect an edge, follow these steps:

title: Connections
content: that you are trying to reconnect

title: Connections
content: list with a new edge based on the

title: Connections
content: , then remove the reference to the old edge from the list

title: Custom nodes
content: Be careful with CSS rules applied to node content. Custom nodes are implemented with SVG's foreignObject element, and Safari has issues with some CSS rules inside foreignObject. Therefore, please check this browser when applying complex styling.

title: Migrations

title: Migrations

title: Migrations
content: remove imports of VflowModule and use Vflow instead (Vflow contains all public standalone components and directives).for standalone components, simply add Vflow to the imports array.for modules, you need to spread ...Vflow into the imports array; otherwise, you will get a type error.remove usage of the computeLayersOnInit setting from the Optimization interface.remove usage of the handlePositions input in the VflowComponent.for classes extending CustomNodeComponent and CustomDynamicNodeComponent:replace this.node to this.node() due to signal input internal migration.
